ticket.tag: action_view block bugmash form_helper form_tag_helper label label_tag patch to_label_tag verified
ticket.title: Let label helpers accept blocks
ticket.original-body: Label helpers should process blocks in addition to their defaults because it's common for their content to have more complex markup than text. This, for example, @@@ <%= f.label :terms, "Accept #{link_to 'Terms', terms_path}" %> @@@ Is much easier to read in a block @@@ <% f.label :terms do %> Accept <%= link_to "Terms", terms_path %> <% end %> @@@ An additional perk: in our editors, the HTML markup won't be lost in Ruby string syntax highlighting. Patch with tests in comments.
ticket.latest-body: Label helpers should process blocks in addition to their defaults because it's common for their content to have more complex markup than text. This, for example, @@@ <%= f.label :terms, "Accept #{link_to 'Terms', terms_path}" %> @@@ Is much easier to read in a block @@@ <% f.label :terms do %> Accept <%= link_to "Terms", terms_path %> <% end %> @@@ An additional perk: in our editors, the HTML markup won't be lost in Ruby string syntax highlighting. Patch with tests in comments.
ticket.original-body-html:
Label helpers should process blocks in addition to their defaults because it's common for their content to have more complex markup than text.

This, for example,

<%= f.label :terms, "<span>Accept #{link_to 'Terms', terms_path}</span>" %>

Is much easier to read in a block

<% f.label :terms do %>
  <span>Accept <%= link_to "Terms", terms_path %></span>
<% end %>

An additional perk: in our editors, the HTML markup won't be lost in Ruby string syntax highlighting.

Patch with tests in comments.

version.body: Label helpers should process blocks in addition to their defaults because it's common for their content to have more complex markup than text. This, for example, @@@ <%= f.label :terms, "Accept #{link_to 'Terms', terms_path}" %> @@@ Is much easier to read in a block @@@ <% f.label :terms do %> Accept <%= link_to "Terms", terms_path %> <% end %> @@@ An additional perk: in our editors, the HTML markup won't be lost in Ruby string syntax highlighting. Patch with tests in comments.
version.body-html:
Label helpers should process blocks in addition to their defaults because it's common for their content to have more complex markup than text.

This, for example,

<%= f.label :terms, "<span>Accept #{link_to 'Terms', terms_path}</span>" %>

Is much easier to read in a block

<% f.label :terms do %>
  <span>Accept <%= link_to "Terms", terms_path %></span>
<% end %>

An additional perk: in our editors, the HTML markup won't be lost in Ruby string syntax highlighting.

Patch with tests in comments.
version.title: Let label helpers accept blocks

version.tag: action_view block form_helper form_tag_helper label label_tag to_label_tag
version.title: Let label helpers accept blocks

version.diffable-attributes: --- :tag: action_view block form_helper form_tag_helper label label_tag to_label_tag
version.tag: action_view block form_helper form_tag_helper label label_tag patch to_label_tag
version.title: Let label helpers accept blocks

version.body:
Double bonus for this enhancement -thanks Stephen. I see that you have also made the "name" attribute optional -fantastic. Now one can implicitly apply a label to the enclosed input without having to worry about id matching with the 'for' attribute:
label_tag nil, "Your Name" do text_field_tag 'name' end
IMO, the signature of #label_tag (and #label) should evolve to better support this practice as it reduces the need to keep DOM ids in sync between the input and the label. Perhaps by counting args to label_tag and assuming a single string argument is a contextual label.
version.body-html:
Double bonus for this enhancement -thanks Stephen. I see that you have also made the "name" attribute optional -fantastic. Now one can implicitly apply a label to the enclosed input without having to worry about id matching with the 'for' attribute:

label_tag nil, "Your Name" do
text_field_tag 'name' end

IMO, the signature of #label_tag (and #label) should evolve to better support this practice as it reduces the need to keep DOM ids in sync between the input and the label. Perhaps by counting args to label_tag and assuming a single string argument is a contextual label.
version.tag: action_view block form_helper form_tag_helper label label_tag patch to_label_tag
version.title: Let label helpers accept blocks

version.body:
Pretty cool!
I use a lot of labels with images inside, especially on radiobuttons and checkboxes to be able to check the corresponding field without having to resort to javascript, and things usually get very messy having to add them inside the label and label_tag methods. So this patch is something i'm realy looking for! Do you need help with anything?
version.body-html:
Pretty cool!

I use a lot of labels with images inside, especially on radiobuttons and checkboxes to be able to check the corresponding field without having to resort to javascript, and things usually get very messy having to add them inside the label and label_tag methods. So this patch is something i'm realy looking for! Do you need help with anything?
version.tag: action_view block form_helper form_tag_helper label label_tag patch to_label_tag
version.title: Let label helpers accept blocks

version.body:
Biggest help would be to test the patch out and get others to do so.
Once a few people approve, we can mark this "confirmed."
version.body-html:
Biggest help would be to test the patch out and get others to do so.

Once a few people approve, we can mark this "confirmed."
